data.text: Contents
Surveillance of fetal growth antenatally and SGA management / MSESOP-21017/1.0
Page  of
Introduction
This SOP describes the responsibilities and process to follow in screening for small babies.

Monitoring the growth of the fetus is important in identifying small babies that may also be growth restricted babies. There is enough evidence in the literature to suggest that the perinatal mortality is high in small and often growth restricted babies. If these babies are identified antenatally and managed appropriately, then this will lead to significant improvement in survival. There are many different approaches to achieving this but locally our methods of screening consist of:
Obstetric history;
First trimester serum markers;
Uterine artery Dopplers at 20 weeks;
Symphysis fundal height measurements (SFH) from  weeks to the onset of labour; SFH measurements are taken from  weeks for Mid Essex Women
Routine third trimester scan at 36 weeks gestation with fetal Dopplers.
Scope
This SOP is relevant to all healthcare professionals involved in the care of pregnant women including Midwives, student midwives, Obstetricians, sonographers and research fellows.
It will inform healthcare workers of:
The risk assessment;
Definitions of small for dates (Small for Gestational Age) and Intrauterine Growth Restriction;
When to refer for a suspected growth abnormality.
The purpose of this document is to:
Ensure a uniform approach to fetal growth surveillance and signpost any concerns appropriately.
Definitions

table_items.text: Will refer to a fetus that has failed to reach a specific estimated fetal weight by a specific gestation. This fetus may not necessarily be growth restricted. AC < 5th centile for that gestational age with normal liquor volume and Doppler. Severe SGA is growth below the 3rd centile, normal liquor volume and Dopplers. It is estimated that 50-60% of fetuses born weighing less than the 10th centile for gestational age are constitutionally small.
FGR occurs when there is a reduction in the growth velocity especially affecting the AC. There may or may not be abnormal Dopplers. Late onset FGR: May present only with Doppler abnormalities.
Umbilical artery: the blood flow through the umbilical artery in the umbilical cord is the assessed. The measurement evaluates blood flow from the fetus to the placenta.
Middle Cerebral Artery is the largest of the three arteries that channels blood to the brain.
Pulsality Index is used to assess resistance in a vascular system.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities within the Trust

The Obstetrics and Gynaecology Guideline Steering Group is responsible for ensuring clinical guidelines are evidence-based and developed in line with national guidelines and following appropriate consultation.
The clinical lead/ medical director is responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the directorate.
The Head of Midwifery, maternity matrons and maternity managers are responsible for ensuring maternity staff are aware of the guideline and implement it.
The Lead Consultant for the Fetal Medicine Unit is responsible for ensuring the implementation of this guideline within the clinical setting.
All maternity staff are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with this guideline in relation to their practice and have the appropriate skills to implement this guideline.
Screening

Surveillance for potential growth restricted babies' starts from the beginning of the pregnancy. Women with positive screening tests such as first trimester serum markers or second trimester uterine artery Doppler would be a trigger for serial ultrasound .
Factors to be taken into account when assessing risks for growth restriction:
(See Appendix 1 for risk assessment).

Low PAPP A levels are actioned by the Antenatal Screeners who will generate scans following the Anomaly scan. The scans will be requested for  and  weeks.
Risk assessment

5.5.1  The risk assessment is completed at the Anomaly scan (see appendix 1). If there are any triggers a scan will be requested to check the growth, liquor and Dopplers at 28 weeks and 32 weeks. This scan request will be generated from Fetal Medicine Unit (FMU) and performed in the Women's Clinic or Fetal Medicine SGA clinic depending on the risk.
Symphysis–fundal height (SFH) measurements

5.6.1 This is the assessment of the size of the mother's uterus by measuring the fundal height. This is a screening tool which will commence at 28 weeks (SFH measurements are taken from 26 weeks at Broomfield hospital) and will continue until the onset of labour. The measurement is performed every 2-3 weeks and is recorded as whole centimetres on the non-customised growth chart (Appendix 2) found in the hand held notes. Women who are having growth scans at 28 and  weeks should still have SFH measurements if they can be measured accurately.
5.6.2 Referral for a scan should be made to the scan department within 3 days if there is:
A plot on or below the th centile;
A plot on or above the th centile;
A flattening of the growth curve;
If the midwife performing the SFH measurement has a concern. This must be clearly documented in the hand held notes.

5.6.3 NB if the woman has recently had a scan (within the last 2 weeks) and the findings were normal, please book the scan 12-14 days from the previous scan. Advise the woman to monitor fetal movements in the interim. If she has any concerns with reduced fetal activity, she should contact MB1at Southend or DAU at Broomfield and inform the midwives at the point of the history taking that she is awaiting a scan due to fundal height measurement concern.

5.6.4 In addition women with maternal medicine concerns i.e. pre-existing diabetics, gestational diabetics and twin pregnancies will have a pre-defined pathway to follow. (Refer to separate guideline).
Diagnosis

This will be by fetal biometry using ultrasound. Biometric measurements used to assess the fetal size are head circumference, abdominal circumference and femur length. All or a combination of these could be used to estimate the fetal weight.
Currently the Hadlock formula is used to estimate the baby's weight.
Liquor volume and umbilical artery Doppler assessments provide additional information.

Abdominal circumference and estimated fetal weight provide the most accurate way of predicting growth restriction or large for gestational age. The trend of growth is valuable in predicting adverse outcome.
Third trimester scans

There is yet to be a reliable test which predicts which pregnancies are at risk of developing growth restriction. Surveillance of fetal growth restriction in the third trimester of pregnancy continues to be the mainstay for the assessment of fetal well- being. A recent study of nulliparous, singleton pregnancies who were scanned at 36 weeks gestation tripled the sensitivity of detection of small for gestation ages and could identify fetal growth restricted babies who are at an increased risk of neonatal morbidity and stillbirth.
Locally we offer a combination of two surveillances such as regular fundal height measurements and ultrasound biometry known as the 36 week scan.

All women are offered a scan at around  weeks. This scan appointment is generated from the Fetal Medicine Unit and is performed within the Fetal Medicine Unit by fellows. At Broomfield hospital the scan is generated by the obstetric scan department and is performed by Sonographers in the department.
The  week scan checks the growth, liquor and Dopplers. In addition presentation is checked and also placental localisation.
Review of scans
Small for gestational age (SGA)
If the fetus is found to be small for gestational age (SGA): i.e. has an estimated fetal weight (EFW) or an abdominal circumference (AC) below the th centile, then refer to
the SGA management flowchart (Appendix 3).

Please note that if the ultrasound scan identifying SGA has normal liquor volume and Doppler studies and has been performed in the Fetal Medicine Unit, then book into the SGA clinic in 2 weeks. However, if the ultrasound scan has NOT been performed in the Fetal Medicine Unit, then book into the NEXT SGA clinic.
EFW or AC below th Book into SGA clinic in centile.  Normal liquor volume  2 weeks. Give RCOG
and Doppler studies  information leaflet USS performed in FMU  “Having a small baby”
Book in to NEXT SGA clinic.
Give RCOG information leaflet
“Having a small baby”
Growth or AC under the 10th centile with oligohydramnios or abnormal Dopplers require referral to the FMU consultant.
Polyhydramnios (defined as a deepest pool of liquor > 8 cms) with or without EFW > 95th centile: refer to MB1/DAU and exclude gestational diabetes.

Polyhydramnios with or without EFW > 95th centile requires home blood glucose monitoring (HBGM) to be taught. This can be facilitated by the Fetal Medicine Clinic MSW. Care will be planned as per local guideline. At Broomfield hospital Home Blood Glucose Monitoring for Polyhydramnios is not carried out.

Breech presentation: Women should be referred to their named consultant or next available Antenatal clinic appointment for any consultant. If the woman is not booked for an elective caesarean section and is already under consultant care an appointment is to be made within 1 week. In the event of the consultant being on leave then an appointment should be made with the consultant on call for the day. This may require clinics to be overbooked. If the woman is low risk then she will be reviewed on MB1 at Southend. At Broomfield hospital the woman will be reviewed by the Antenatal clinic midwife . The woman should be directed to review the online patient information leaflet on ECV. The woman is counselled by the midwives and if ECV accepted then that is to be booked as per ECV guideline. If the woman declines an ECV then she should be reviewed by the registrar/consultant at next available clinic.
Low lying placenta: An appointment is to be made within 1 week with the named consultant. If the pregnancy is low risk then the woman needs to be seen in the on call consultant's clinic in 1 week.
Training requirements
No specific training requirements.
Monitoring and audit

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Obstetrics and Gynaecology Guideline Steering Group (which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document Control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the stakeholders of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 4)
